The clear() method does the job.  It sets the pointed back to the first open slot so that it can be overwritten.  This is much faster than clearing the entire buffer or allocating a new one, and for these purposes, works well, now that I also removed the peek() method.

These changes will break backwards compatibility, so all of these changes will need to be documented as breaking in the lib/cpp/README.md, in the top level CHANGES.  The code will be cleaner and standards compliant in the end, which I think is a good thing.  Folks can continue to use 0.12.0 and earlier to remain compatible with the code they have now.
I just chip in to say a bit "thank you"! I'm looking forward to a more C++-1-based codebase. Two thumbs up!
I'll follow this up with a change to the cpp readme, top level changes, and top level languages files.
Darnit.  I meant to squash this into one commit, but I rebased it instead!  *grumble*

I'm actually a big fan of removing branches like this, especially if they are not used.  Given how deep the pipelines are in CPUs today, a branch misprediction is expensive, and return value checking requires additional unit testing of both branches.  With exceptions to handle issues both of these problems are eliminated.

It's unfortunate this leads to another breaking change however... I think that's more fodder to call the next release 1.0.0 :)
I'd love if someone could help get this across the finish line. I'm comfortable with the Dart side of things but not so much with all the CI details on this project.

Here's a reproduction of one of the cross test build failures using the docker container:

### First get into the container:
```
jking@ubuntu:~$ cd thrift
jking@ubuntu:~/thrift$ docker run -v $(pwd):/thrift/src:rw -it thrift/thrift-build:ubuntu-bionic /bin/bash
root@600c82e93c89:/thrift/src#
```

### Run precross to prepare targets:
```
root@600c82e93c89:/thrift/src# ./bootstrap.sh && ./configure && make precross -j3
```

### Run a set of tests:
```
root@cd37d55d3a12:/thrift/src# test/test.py --skip-known-failures --server go --client dart --regex '.*binary.*'
```

Then you can look at the log subdirectory for output including the commands used to run it.

NOTE since your PR has modifications to the docker container you will need to build it and then run it.   My example above pulls the latest container from master which is built through CI and pushed to docker hub automatically.
@jeking3 I am not sure whether to remove pthread_mutux* from mutex.h?
Is there anything that still uses it?  Shouldn't it all be `<mutex>` now?
Only mutex and related tests use pthread  lib

The goal is to remove any platform-specific thread or mutex concepts and use the C++11 standard, so I would say pthread has to go.  In fact, given how the changes in place are already breaking, I would suggest removing PlatformThreadFactory.h as it really doesn't serve much of a purpose now.
@jeking3 Checking this into the V1 branch?  Should I document as broken starting with V1 or V0.12?
A change like this would not be pulled into a 0.12.0 refresh for a language.  This would be in the next major release which is currently 1.0 (although that could change).

Since we're not eliminating the StdMutex class, we still need a unit test for the resulting Mutex class. (could rename StdMutex.cpp / .h to Mutex.cpp / .h, etc...)  I think your PR removed the unit test which is incorrect.  Removing the pthreads compile-time branches, sure. :)

> 
> 
> Since we're not eliminating the StdMutex class, we still need a unit test for the resulting Mutex class. (could rename StdMutex.cpp / .h to Mutex.cpp / .h, etc...) I think your PR removed the unit test which is incorrect. Removing the pthreads compile-time branches, sure. :)

Those unit tests would test the deleted code of pthread_mutex*,so I have deleted them.
Adding new tests for std::thread should be in another PR.
Closing this and doing the additional work needed on my fork, since builds are getting delayed.

While this removed the runtime dynamic library dependencies on boost, it did not remove the requirement to have boost headers present to build the runtime library.  While boost is required to run the tests, it shouldn't be required to just build the CPP library.  There are about 40 more mentions of boost in the lib/cpp/src headers that need to be converted to std concepts, if they exist; or in the case of boost::noncopyable, do something else.  Note that the pull request for THRIFT-4441 had a solution for this.

As long as it gets done.

You deleted your branch after submitting the PR?

Please rebase on master as the issue seen in these builds was resolved.
In case you are not familiar with that:

1. git checkout master
2. git pull
3. git checkout fix-test
4. git rebase master
5. git push -u (your github repo-name, like "origin", "personal", etc..) fix-test --force

This will kick off another build with fixes for the build issues seen.

There are already a number of breaking changes in C++ and Java for 0.13.0... not sure deprecation is necessary in this case as people can still download 0.12.0, but if we want to have three of them for one release that's okay too.

One more comment - all other languages use singular package names, i.e. Thrift.Protocol, Thrift.Transport; here we have Thrift.Protocols and Thrift.Transports.  I think we should stick to the convention used by other languages (all of them) and use singular package names.

@jeking3: Thanks for the review. I find it interesting that I only have to copy over stuff from netcore to become the one being blamed for the exact same code that is in the repo already. To think that someone proposed just a few days ago that netcore should be the new standard C# library  

Next, the filters file ... I can remove it, but why is it in the repo in the first place then?

> Shouldn't most of these be true if we're establishing a new baseline?

Again, no. Nobody who has a sane mind wants to use that union stuff. Next, switching around flags makes migration harder as necessary. And nullable ... I plan to remove that from the new netstd library, because it makes maintenance much harder and the net value of it is not as expected. It's basically a burden, not a feature (and if you ask me, the union stuff should be thrown out as well).
Could you also provide a small example (perhaps in a test subdirectory) of how this is used?

> If this closes #1519 please put "This closes #1519" in the description.

No, it doesn't. This PR and #1519 touches on the same subject (map<i64, ...>) but are different. 
This fixes the constant generation while #1519 fixes key serialization -according to my understanding.

I tried to create an example in a subdirectory but it somehow would not fit. Any example I could provide would make sense as a downstream project, not as a part of thrift. I think the `CMakeLists.txt` inside a thrift subdirectory may be confusing?

In any case, here is a slightly extensive `CMakeLists.txt` for a hypothetical library `CMakeThriftTest` that has a source file `src/CMakeThriftTest.cc` and a Thrift IDL file `thrift/TestAPI.thrift`. The thrift compiler checks are just there for the sake of demonstration and are not mandatory, but they test the compiler execution and may be helpful to check the compiler version.

The important part is, thanks to cmake package configuration, this example should work without `FindThrift.cmake` script, as long as cmake has the installation path of thrift in its search path (but this is anyways required for the prerequisites).

```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.0 FATAL_ERROR)
project(CMakeThriftTest)

find_package(thrift REQUIRED)

# Checking if a thrift compiler is available. This is not required but may be helpful:
if(NOT THRIFT_COMPILER)
    message(FATAL_ERROR "Could not detect thrift compiler")
else()
    execute_process(COMMAND "${THRIFT_COMPILER}" --version TIMEOUT 10 OUTPUT_VARIABLE THRIFT_VERSION_STRING RESULT_VARIABLE THRIFT_RETURN_VALUE)
    string(STRIP "${THRIFT_VERSION_STRING}" THRIFT_VERSION_STRING)
    string(REGEX MATCH "^Thrift version ([0-9]+)\\.([0-9]+)\\.([0-9]+)$" THRIFT_VERSION_NUMBER "${THRIFT_VERSION_STRING}")
    message("Found thrift compiler version '${CMAKE_MATCH_1}.${CMAKE_MATCH_2}.${CMAKE_MATCH_3}' at '${THRIFT_COMPILER}'")
endif()

set(THRIFT_IDL_FILE "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/thrift/TestAPI.thrift")
set(THRIFT_HEADER_FILES_LIST
    "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp/APIAccess.h"
    "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp/TestAPI_constants.h"
    "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp/TestAPI_types.h")
set(THRIFT_SOURCE_FILES_LIST
    "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp/APIAccess.cpp"
    "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp/TestAPI_constants.cpp"
    "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp/TestAPI_types.cpp")

# automatically generate Thrift sources:
add_custom_command(
    OUTPUT ${THRIFT_SOURCE_FILES_LIST} ${THRIFT_HEADER_FILES_LIST}
    COMMAND "${THRIFT_COMPILER}" -strict -recurse -o "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/" -gen cpp "${THRIFT_IDL_FILE}")

set(SOURCES
    include/CMakeThriftTest.hh
    src/CMakeThriftTest.cc
    ${THRIFT_SOURCE_FILES_LIST}
    ${THRIFT_HEADER_FILES_LIST})

add_library(${PROJECT_NAME} ${SOURCES})

target_include_directories(${PROJECT_NAME}
    PRIVATE
        ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src
        ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp
        ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}
    PUBLIC
        $<BUILD_INTERFACE:${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/include>
        $<INSTALL_INTERFACE:include>
        ${THRIFT_INCLUDE_DIR})

target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME}
    PUBLIC
        thrift::thrift Threads::Threads
    PRIVATE
        $<$<PLATFORM_ID:Windows>:wsock32> $<$<PLATFORM_ID:Windows>:ws2_32>)

install(TARGETS ${PROJECT_NAME}
    ARCHIVE DESTINATION lib
    LIBRARY DESTINATION lib
    RUNTIME DESTINATION bin
    INCLUDES DESTINATION include)
install(DIRECTORY include/ DESTINATION include)
install(FILES ${THRIFT_HEADER_FILES_LIST} DESTINATION include)
```

Looks good, some comments:

I agree that having it under the existing projects does not make sense.  It could be a separate project in tutorial/cmake that we explicitly build separately AFTER we do a cmake build and cmake install in CI.

As for the cmake itself:

1. find_package is supposed to handle versioning requirements.  I would not expect to have to run the compiler with --version and capture the output and regex it in the consuming cmake module.

2. It would be "better" (but understandably perhaps too difficult) to know the resulting generated file structure and make it part of dependencies.  So maybe that's just the way it is (that's how I have done it in the past).

3. I would expect any integration to provide a macro for "thrift_compile" instead of add_custom_command (I would wrap that in a macro myself in my own project).

4. Generated code should go into CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR, however there is a directive indicating private headers live in ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/src/gen-cpp, so that looks like a mistake.  CMake out-of-tree builds should succeed even if the source tree is read-only.

Thanks - good to see cmake action in the project.  There is a lot to do in order to cut over to cmake from autoconf...
See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-4759

Dear @jeking, I agree to all your points about the cmake example. However I feel it would be good to proceed with this PR independent of the usage example. The important part is that the PR adds the required steps to allow inclusion of thrift without the need for a (manually crafted, explicitly added) find-script. This will significantly help downstream packages. Since the use of `find_package(thrift)` is almost trivial, I think the PR adds its value independently of the usage example.

This PR is same with https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1713.
Given that the support for GNU autotools is not dropped,I decided to add the cmake generated header to the source tree.And the header was changed a little to avoid errors in gcc/clang.
And I only added the macro to problematic locations.
